title: Why do enzymes catalyze a specific reaction? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is not everywhere true. There are several enzymes that catalyze a specific class of reaction but can use different substrates, so many specific reactions (ie. all the reagents and products are the same molecules) can be carried out by a single enzyme. However, these are variations on a theme. Two examples of these enzymes are the cytochrome P-450 family and penicillinase. The former is a family of enzymes that metabolizes drugs and poisons, but each member of the family metabolizes several different drugs in a similar way. The latter can hydrolyze the beta-lactam ring of a variety of different penicillin-derived drugs. All enzymes work by decreasing the activation energy of a reaction through a number of mechanisms. Often, these mechanisms are dependent on binding and holding the substrates (or a class of substrates) in a specific orientation and configuration to dramatically increase the likelihood of reaction. This requires the enzymes to recognize and bind specifically to the substrates, and this specificity limits the range of reactions and range of substrates possible.
